On Jan 4, 2012, at 6:39 PM, Will Hartung wrote:

> On Wed, Jan 4, 2012 at =
5:51 AM, Jan Algermissen
> <jan.algermissen@...> wrote:
> 
>> I do n=
ot refer to generic forms. A form is any syntactical construct that instruc=
ts
>> the user agent what data to include in the submission (including fixe=
d (aka
>> 'hidden')) values. My forms would simply be an inherent part of t=
he specific
>> media type(s) I define.
> 
> What makes the "form" stand out=
 from any other part of the data, and
> why should it stand out from any pa=
rt of the data.

Good question.

To me, this is a matter of who is remember=
ing state. Does the client remember all the aspects of an offer to build th=
e order or is the offer a resource that the client can GET and is then give=
n the offer-data as a submittable form?

Jan

> The client will
> need to "=
know" how to build the "form" for the payload anyway, and it
> can source t=
hat data from any part of the original payload as required
> by the specifi=
cs of the call, whether that source data is from a
> "form" or simply part =
of the data.
> 
> Why does the "form" part stand out at all?
> 
> Regards,
=
> 
> Will Hartung
> (willh@...)
